Omar Kelly and Chris Perkins analyze the latest Dolphins' moves in free agency. 
Omar Kelly and Chris Perkins analyze the latest Dolphins' moves in free agency. Dave Hyde off-season plan is a simple one: Pay their own, hand-selected guys whom they know well rather than pay outside free-agents who they only can know so much about.
This is Adam Gase’s way, as I wrote in a recent column , and it’s an interesting take on how to build a team. The common sense is clear. Pay your players. Build “loyalty” and “family” that way. Keep good players together in a manner that’s tough in the world of modern football. 
“I paid the cost for you to win financially,’’ Gase is saying, “Now you pay the cost for all of us to win on the field.” 
The risks? They’re there, too. Bodies age in dog years in football. The Dolphins re-did deals for Reshad Jones , 29 and coming off a shoulder injury, and Kiko Alonso, 27 in August and with some knee issues in his career. Both had a year remaining on their contract. 
This is a nice way to do what is often hard-line business. For instance, the Dolphins could have let Jones play out this year, franchise-tag him for about $14 million next year — and, to be really hard-line, tag him a second year at age 31. That would have been more cost-effective and lots of teams would have done that. 
The Dolphins have chosen a friends-and-family plan. You can appreciate that. Let’s see where it goes now. 
One of Bill Belichick’s pet lines is, “Don’t be afraid to let your players go to free agency.” He’s did that most recently with Dont’a Hightower. He’s thrown players overboard on the edge of free agency for years (Chandler Jones, Jamie Collins , Logan Mankins , Lawyer Milloy …) 
This isn’t to say Belichick’s way is right. Seattle does it a friendlier way. There are a lot of ways up the mountain, and the Dolphins are doing it Gase’s interesting way. Pay your players. Buy their loyalty. And only buy outside free agents for value deals. Guard/center Ted Larsen was a value deal at three years, $5.6 million. Dontari Poe (one year, $8 million with Atlanta) and evidently Zach Brown weren’t. 
In the recent weeks, the Dolphins have done big-dollar deals for Jones, Alonso, Kenny Stills, Andre Branch and Cameron Wake. That’s the start of a foundation Gase has invested to win. 
Alonso was the latest with a four-year, $28.2 million deal. 
Landry would be next. He has a year remaining on his rookie contract, but the Dolphins have shown . We’ll see where this ends up with him. But the Dolphins philosophy is crystal clear. 
Don’t pay for players you don’t know. 
Pay for your own. 
See which players are on the move as the Dolphins continue to revamp their roster in free agency.
